header.subtitle: Comprehensive guide to deploying, configuring, and managing antivirus software across your infrastructure with real-time monitoring and control.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: SysManage provides centralized management of open-source antivirus software across all supported platforms. The platform automates deployment, enables real-time monitoring of antivirus status, and provides tools to enable, disable, or remove antivirus software remotely.

features.service_control: Service Control: Enable or disable antivirus services remotely

features.realtime_status: Real-time Status: Monitor antivirus status, version, and enabled/disabled state

linux.rkhunter: rkhunter - Rootkit Hunter scans for rootkits, backdoors, and local exploits

defaults.title: Setting Default Antivirus Software
defaults.description: SysManage allows administrators to define which antivirus software should be deployed for each operating system. These defaults are used when deploying antivirus to hosts.
defaults.step1: Navigate to Settings in the main menu
defaults.step3: For each operating system, select the desired antivirus package from the dropdown
defaults.step4: Select "None" to disable automatic antivirus deployment for that OS

deployment.title: Deploying Antivirus Software
deployment.overview_description: Antivirus deployment in SysManage is a fully automated process that installs and configures the antivirus software appropriate for the target host's operating system.

requirements.title: Prerequisites
requirements.active_host: Host must be active and connected to the server
requirements.privileged_agent: Agent must be running with elevated privileges (root/administrator)
requirements.default_configured: A default antivirus package must be configured for the host's operating system
requirements.network: Host must have internet access to download antivirus packages

steps.title: Deploying via Web Interface
steps.step1: Navigate to Hosts in the main menu
steps.step2: Click on the desired host to view its details
steps.step3: Scroll to the Antivirus card on the host detail page
steps.step4: If no antivirus is detected, you will see a "Deploy Antivirus" button
steps.step6: Confirm the deployment in the dialog that appears
steps.step7: Monitor the deployment progress - the antivirus card will update when deployment completes

process.title: What Happens During Deployment
process.description: The deployment process varies slightly by platform but generally follows these steps:

linux_bsd.step2: ClamAV and related packages are downloaded and installed
linux_bsd.step3: freshclam service is enabled and started (updates virus definitions)
linux_bsd.step4: clamd service is enabled and started (real-time scanning daemon)
linux_bsd.step5: Initial virus definition update is performed
linux_bsd.step6: Agent reports deployment status back to server

macos.step2: freshclam is configured and virus definitions are updated
macos.step3: ClamAV service is started via brew services

windows.step1: ClamAV for Windows installer is downloaded
windows.step3: ClamAV Windows service is configured and started

header.title: Child Host Management
header.subtitle: Comprehensive guide to creating, managing, and monitoring child hosts including WSL instances, containers, and virtual machines within your SysManage infrastructure.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Child host management in SysManage enables you to create and manage virtualized environments directly from the web interface. This includes Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) instances, LXD/LXC containers, and various virtual machine technologies. Child hosts are automatically registered as managed hosts with the sysmanage-agent pre-installed.

overview.concept_child: Child Host: A virtualized environment (WSL, container, or VM) running on a parent host
overview.concept_distribution: Distribution: The operating system image used to create child hosts (e.g., Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora)
overview.concept_virtualization: Virtualization Type: The technology used (WSL, LXD, VirtualBox, Hyper-V, KVM, etc.)
overview.concept_agent: Agent Auto-Installation: Child hosts automatically receive the sysmanage-agent during creation
overview.type_wsl: WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux): Run Linux distributions on Windows hosts

lxd.title: LXD Container Management
lxd.overview_desc: LXD is a modern container and virtual machine manager for Linux. SysManage integrates with LXD to provide seamless creation and management of Linux containers directly from the web interface.
lxd.req_installed: LXD must be installed on the host (snap or native package)
lxd.req_initialized: LXD must be initialized (lxd init completed)
lxd.req_bridge: A network bridge must be configured (default: lxdbr0)
lxd.req_user: The sysmanage-agent user must be in the lxd group
lxd.detection_desc: SysManage automatically detects LXD capability by checking:
lxd.detect_2: Successful connection to the LXD API
lxd.detect_3: Permission to create and manage containers
lxd.detection_role: When detected, the host is assigned the LXD Host role and LXD appears as an available virtualization type.
lxd.setup_desc: To prepare a host for LXD container management:
lxd.setup_step1: Install LXD: sudo snap install lxd or via package manager
lxd.setup_step2: Initialize LXD: sudo lxd init (accept defaults or customize)
lxd.setup_step3: Add agent user to lxd group: sudo usermod -aG lxd sysmanage-agent
lxd.setup_step4: Restart the sysmanage-agent service to pick up group membership
lxd.creation_desc: When creating an LXD container through SysManage:
lxd.creation_step1: SysManage launches the container from the official cloud image
lxd.creation_step2: Container receives an IP address via DHCP from lxdbr0
lxd.creation_step3: The specified user account is created with sudo privileges
lxd.creation_step4: Package repositories are configured based on the distribution
lxd.creation_step5: The sysmanage-agent is installed (via APT, DNF, or Zypper)
lxd.creation_step6: Agent configuration is generated with server connection details
lxd.creation_step7: The agent service starts and connects to SysManage
lxd.creation_step8: Container appears in the Hosts list pending approval
lxd.networking_desc: LXD containers use the default bridge network:
lxd.net_dhcp: DHCP: Containers receive IP addresses automatically from the lxdbr0 bridge
lxd.net_nat: NAT: Outbound connectivity is provided via NAT through the host
lxd.net_dns: DNS: Containers can resolve external hostnames through the host's DNS configuration
lxd.networking_note: For the container to communicate with the SysManage server, the host must have network access to the server, and the container must be able to route through the host.
lxd.distributions_desc: LXD containers can be created using any distribution where the sysmanage-agent is available:
lxd.comparison_desc: Both LXD and WSL provide containerized Linux environments, but they differ in several ways:
lxd.comparison_platform: Platform: LXD runs on Linux hosts; WSL runs on Windows hosts
lxd.comparison_tech: Technology: LXD uses Linux containers (LXC); WSL uses a Microsoft compatibility layer
lxd.comparison_networking: Networking: LXD containers get routable IPs on lxdbr0; WSL instances share the Windows host network
lxd.comparison_images: Images: LXD pulls from the official image server; WSL uses Microsoft Store distributions
lxd.comparison_features: Features: LXD supports snapshots, profiles, and clustering; WSL focuses on developer tooling integration

kvm.title: KVM/QEMU Virtual Machine Management
kvm.overview_desc: KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a virtualization technology built into the Linux kernel. Combined with QEMU for hardware emulation and libvirt for management, it provides enterprise-grade virtual machine capabilities. SysManage integrates with KVM/libvirt to enable seamless VM creation and lifecycle management from the web interface.
kvm.req_cpu: CPU with hardware virtualization support (Intel VT-x or AMD-V)
kvm.req_kernel: Linux kernel with KVM modules (kvm, kvm_intel or kvm_amd)
kvm.req_network: libvirt default network or custom network bridge configured
kvm.req_user: The sysmanage-agent user must be in the libvirt group
kvm.detection_desc: SysManage automatically detects KVM capability by checking:
kvm.detect_1: KVM kernel modules are loaded (/dev/kvm exists)
kvm.detect_2: libvirt daemon is running and accessible
kvm.detect_3: The virsh command is available and functional
kvm.detect_4: At least one libvirt network is configured
kvm.detection_role: When detected, the host is assigned the KVM Host role and KVM appears as an available virtualization type.
kvm.setup_desc: To prepare a host for KVM virtual machine management:
kvm.setup_step2: Install KVM packages: sudo apt install qemu-kvm libvirt-daemon-system (Debian/Ubuntu) or sudo dnf install qemu-kvm libvirt (Fedora/RHEL)
kvm.setup_step3: Enable and start libvirtd: sudo systemctl enable --now libvirtd
kvm.setup_step4: Add agent user to libvirt group: sudo usermod -aG libvirt sysmanage-agent
kvm.setup_step5: Configure the default network: sudo virsh net-autostart default && sudo virsh net-start default
kvm.setup_step6: Restart the sysmanage-agent service to pick up group membership
kvm.setup_auto: Alternatively, click "Enable KVM" in the SysManage web interface to automate these setup steps.
kvm.creation_desc: When creating a KVM virtual machine through SysManage:
kvm.creation_step1: SysManage downloads the cloud image from the distribution's official source
kvm.creation_step2: A new disk image is created and the cloud image is applied as a backing store
kvm.creation_step3: Cloud-init configuration is generated with hostname, user account, and agent settings
kvm.creation_step4: The VM is defined in libvirt with the specified resources (CPU, memory, disk)
kvm.creation_step5: VM boots and cloud-init configures the system, creates the user, and installs the agent
kvm.creation_step6: The sysmanage-agent service starts and connects to your SysManage server
kvm.creation_step7: The VM appears in the Hosts list pending approval (or auto-approved if selected)
kvm.form_desc: When creating KVM VMs, additional configuration options are available:
kvm.field_vm_name: VM Name: The libvirt domain name (must be unique on the host)
kvm.field_cpus: vCPUs: Number of virtual CPUs - default is 2
kvm.field_disk: Disk Size: Virtual disk size (e.g., "20G", "50G") - default is 20GB
kvm.networking_desc: KVM VMs connect to the libvirt default network which provides:
kvm.net_dhcp: DHCP: VMs receive IP addresses automatically from the virbr0 bridge (typically 192.168.122.x)
kvm.net_nat: NAT: Outbound connectivity is provided via NAT through the host
kvm.net_dns: DNS: VMs use the host's DNS servers for name resolution
kvm.networking_bridged: For advanced networking, SysManage also supports bridged mode where VMs get IP addresses directly from your network's DHCP server.
kvm.lifecycle_desc: Once created, KVM VMs support the full range of lifecycle operations:
kvm.lifecycle_stop: Stop: Gracefully shutdown the VM using virsh shutdown
kvm.lifecycle_delete: Delete: Remove the VM and its storage using virsh undefine --remove-all-storage

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.issue1_sol1: Verify the parent host has network connectivity
troubleshooting.issue1_sol2: Check that the distribution is enabled in Settings
troubleshooting.issue1_sol3: Ensure sufficient disk space on the parent host
troubleshooting.issue1_sol4: Review the error message in the child host status
troubleshooting.issue2_desc: This is normal behavior. Use SysManage's reboot function to restart the Windows host, then retry creating child hosts.
troubleshooting.issue3_sol1: Verify the child host is running (not stopped)
troubleshooting.issue3_sol2: Check that the sysmanage-agent service is running inside the child
troubleshooting.issue3_sol3: Verify network connectivity from the child to the SysManage server
troubleshooting.issue3_sol4: Review the agent logs for connection errors
troubleshooting.issue4_desc: Click on the child host to view the error details. Common causes include:
troubleshooting.issue5_desc: If LXD container creation fails, check the following:
troubleshooting.issue5_sol1: Verify LXD is initialized: lxc list should work without errors
troubleshooting.issue5_sol2: Check lxdbr0 network exists: lxc network list
troubleshooting.issue5_sol3: Ensure sysmanage-agent user is in the lxd group: groups sysmanage-agent
troubleshooting.issue6_desc: If the container starts but has no network connectivity:
troubleshooting.issue6_sol1: Verify lxdbr0 is running: lxc network show lxdbr0
troubleshooting.issue6_sol2: Check container network config: lxc config show CONTAINER
troubleshooting.issue6_sol3: Verify DHCP is working: lxc exec CONTAINER -- ip addr
troubleshooting.issue6_sol4: Try restarting the network: lxc restart CONTAINER
troubleshooting.issue7_desc: If a host with LXD installed doesn't show the LXD Host role:
troubleshooting.issue7_sol1: Verify LXD socket exists and is accessible
troubleshooting.issue7_sol2: Check sysmanage-agent user has lxd group membership
troubleshooting.issue7_sol3: Restart sysmanage-agent after adding to lxd group
troubleshooting.issue7_sol4: Wait for the next role detection cycle or restart the agent
troubleshooting.issue8_title: LXD Container Agent Shows Not Privileged
troubleshooting.issue8_desc: This is expected behavior. LXD containers run unprivileged by default for security. The agent will report its capabilities accordingly. The container can still be fully managed, but some privileged operations (like installing certain packages) may require configuration changes.

header.title: Container Engine Module
header.description: Lightweight container lifecycle management for WSL and LXD instances, including creation, start/stop/restart/delete, distribution management, and real-time monitoring.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: The Container Engine module provides unified management of lightweight containers across WSL (Windows) and LXD (Linux) platforms. Detect host capabilities, provision new instances with automatic agent installation, manage their complete lifecycle, and administer WSL distributions.

opensource.title: Open Source vs Professional+
opensource.description: The open-source Community Edition of SysManage includes read-only listing of child hosts (containers and VMs) that are detected by the agent. The Professional+ Container Engine module adds full lifecycle management capabilities:

opensource.lifecycle: Professional+: Create, start, stop, restart, and delete containers
opensource.distributions: Professional+: WSL distribution management (create, update, delete)
opensource.monitoring: Professional+: Advanced container monitoring and statistics

reboot_orchestration.meta_description: Safe parent host reboot with automatic child host stop and restart orchestration for WSL and LXD containers.

header.title: Reboot Orchestration Module
header.description: Safe parent host reboot with automatic child host orchestration. Cleanly stops running containers before reboot, then automatically restarts them after the host comes back online.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: The Reboot Orchestration module provides a safe, automated workflow for rebooting parent hosts that have running child hosts (WSL or LXD containers). Instead of abruptly rebooting and risking data loss in containers, the orchestrator follows a controlled sequence to ensure all children are cleanly stopped before the reboot and automatically restarted afterward.

opensource.title: Open Source vs Professional+
opensource.description: The open-source Community Edition includes a pre-check endpoint that warns about running child hosts before a reboot. The Professional+ Reboot Orchestration module adds full automated orchestration:
opensource.pre_check: Community Edition: Pre-check warning shows running child hosts before reboot
opensource.orchestrated: Professional+: Automated stop, reboot, and restart orchestration
opensource.tracking: Professional+: Real-time orchestration status tracking with timestamps
opensource.recovery: Professional+: Automatic child host recovery after parent reboot

state_machine.title: Orchestration State Machine
state_machine.description: Each orchestrated reboot follows a well-defined state machine. The orchestration progresses through these states:

shutting_down.label: shutting_down
shutting_down.desc: Stop commands sent to all running child hosts; waiting for confirmation

rebooting.label: rebooting
rebooting.desc: All children stopped; reboot command issued to parent host

pending_restart.label: pending_restart
pending_restart.desc: Parent host is rebooting; waiting for agent to reconnect

restarting.label: restarting
restarting.desc: Agent reconnected; start commands sent for previously-running children

failed.label: failed
failed.desc: One or more child hosts failed to restart; error details available

api.title: API Reference
api.description: The Reboot Orchestration module provides three API endpoints:

pre_check.title: Reboot Pre-Check (Open Source)
pre_check.description: Returns information about running child hosts so the user can make an informed decision before rebooting. Available in the open-source Community Edition.

orchestrated.title: Orchestrated Reboot (Pro+)
orchestrated.description: Initiates an orchestrated reboot sequence. Stops all running child hosts, reboots the parent, and automatically restarts children after the agent reconnects. Requires a Professional+ license with the container_engine module.
orchestrated.error_402: Professional+ license required. Upgrade to access orchestrated reboot.
orchestrated.error_400: Host is not active, or no running child hosts found.

status.title: Orchestration Status
status.description: Returns the current status of a reboot orchestration, including timestamps for each phase and per-child restart status.

frontend.title: Frontend Behavior
frontend.description: When rebooting a parent host with running child hosts, the frontend provides an enhanced experience:
frontend.pre_check_dialog: The reboot dialog shows a pre-check summary of running child hosts
frontend.orchestrated_option: With Pro+, an "Orchestrated Reboot" button replaces the standard reboot for hosts with children
frontend.progress_polling: A progress indicator polls the orchestration status endpoint to show real-time state transitions
frontend.completion_notification: A notification is shown when the orchestration completes or if any children fail to restart

timeouts.title: Timeout and Error Handling
timeouts.description: The orchestration service includes built-in safeguards to handle failures at any stage:
timeouts.shutdown_timeout: Shutdown timeout: If child hosts do not stop within the configured timeout (default 120 seconds), the reboot proceeds anyway
timeouts.agent_reconnect: Agent reconnect: The orchestration transitions from "rebooting" to "restarting" when the parent's agent sends its first heartbeat after reboot
timeouts.partial_failure: Partial failure: If some children fail to restart, the orchestration completes with an error message indicating which children failed
timeouts.audit_logging: Audit logging: All orchestration events are recorded in the audit log for compliance and troubleshooting

requirements.permissions: User must have the REBOOT_HOST security role
